channel.title: davewiner tweets
channel.description: A feed of recent tweets from davewiner.

item.description: @rbergin @markos to lock in the votes in favor of the ruling.
@markos I've been saying the same thing. Why doesn't anyone else see this.

The best book on Microsoft was written by David Bank, and unfortunately almost no one read it because it came out the week of 9/11. But if you want to know what really happened it's authoritative imho. https://t.co/82pmpIes0s
I had inside sources myself and wrote about it in my blog in the 90s. Bank covered Microsoft for the WSJ, so his sources were probably better. But we both saw the same thing, a huge disconnect between the top guy and reality.

One of the things Facebook does better than Twitter is the way they write browser-based JS modules as their API instead of server-based APIs. That way: 1. The API is *much* simpler. 2. I don't have to run a server as an intermediary. 3. The uptake of new APIs would be faster.
Andreessen Horowitz explains the crypto hype cycle. https://t.co/MvoQy0LUVm
@ElieNYC heh you quoted artie bucco. nice.
@mterenzio Totally agree.

Another fallout of the crypto meltdown are the icons of tech doing and saying crazy things trying to save their investments. Did some of them believe their own hype? If so that violates one of the prime rules of hucksterism. https://t.co/KaVSIWOxW9 https://t.co/zakesDgDsi
One of the reasons tech has been able to get away with massive decade-long scams is that the press generally treats the industry like a transparent black box. As if everything inside is always as they say it is.
Can you blame them for taking advantage of this disconnect>?
I think journalism has some explaining to do, for example, about the crisis caused by Cambridge Analytica.
The features they were using in 2016 were announced and deployed with great fanfare in 2012.
As a developer and a blogger, I loved their APIs and wrote about them, but I was also aware of the great power they gave to anyone. This was at a time when there was great worldwide optimism about "the open graph."
Its name should have raised questions but they didn't. Journalism went along with the hype, fully buying into the idea that Zuck was a benevolent tech dictator. He knew what was best and could be trusted.
It's as if journalism had forgotten why tech can't be trusted. They had no memory of the browser wars, cutting off air supplies (look it up), all the abuses of Microsoft in the 90s and what it led to.
What they should've been doing is asking questions, poking around looking for the hidden trap door, which certainly was there.
Dogecoin co-creator calls Elon Musk a 'grifter' who had trouble running basic code. https://t.co/tmUPJTf1Q0
Democrats Voted In GOP Primary to Block Trumpâ€™s Picks. https://t.co/pvmmb80vCg
Dogecoin's Jackson Palmer on Elon Musk, crypto bubble, Pauline Hanson. https://t.co/0apM7x1ggx
Is anyone still paying attention to COVID-19 trends? https://t.co/g9o8dHOX5I
How the Right Rigs the Book Game. https://t.co/vCjWXKLNTQ
The Best Bagels In NYC. https://t.co/iFKU8yqxKK
Wuling Hongguang Mini EV Review: Cheap Electric City Car. https://t.co/3GdaAsx46u
@SBenhoff @KashPrime More likely Turbo Pascal.
Paradox of tolerance. https://t.co/zoscSexmFY
A fundamental law of the internet. Online groups that give everyone an equal voice devolve into bullshit. It's just a matter of time. Always happens. No exceptions.
Elon Musk: When I saw the Tesla CEO for who he really is. https://t.co/HVfNJIA4jz
Private property. https://t.co/Psg0ukTnpA
"Some men just want to watch the world burn." https://t.co/kv1tQ9Sl5r
Seeing Jack say what he just said, I guess the crypto people are just bomb throwers now, like the maga's. What a world. https://t.co/kv1tQ9Sl5r

I subscribe to the NYT and WP, both have the concept of "gifting" articles. 10 per month per subscriber. By the end of the month I have a bunch of free gifts left over -- if I don't use them they'll go to waste.
Wonder if there isn't a way to pool our gift links and put them to some good communal use?
For example, here's a gift link to a story about rail trails for biking in the US.
https://t.co/zhNwk5KqSt
